answers.answer: Controversial question.Much of the research says "no" but hypothyroidism is often seen in PCOS patients and viceversa.http://www.netdoctor.co.uk/womenshealth/facts/pcos.htmhttp://www.pcosupport.org/medical/thatcher1.phphttp://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0CYD/is_19_36/ai_81006734In my family (of six thyroid patients) three of us have PCOS.  I've had both of my ovaries removed because of it.PCOS is linked to Type II diabetes.  Thyroid problems have a correlation with Type II diabetes.  A higher than average number of PCOS patients have thyroid problems.  They are all endocrine related.Personally, I just think the link hasn't been found yet.

What are your other relatives that have thyroid issues and PCOS taking?  Thanks!I'd been on metformin which worked really well at keeping my cycles normal but I took myself off of it after a year and a half as I had some bad gastric distress (probably because of not eating well) and then I was officially diagnosed with Hashimoto's so the doctor said I could keep off of it and start Synthroid (taking generic).  I've been on it since mid-December but wonder if I should take metformin as well.  My glucose tolerance test was in the normal range.  Just got labs back since going on thyroid meds and haveT3, Free -- 265;T4, Free, non-dialysis -- .99TSH -- 3.5Best,Pam
